newsitem.title: CONGO: Gabon Ebola deaths now at 11 from 18 cases - WHO.
newsitem.headline: Gabon Ebola deaths now at 11 from 18 cases - WHO.

text.p: An outbreak of the Ebola virus in Gabon has killed 11 people from 18 cases, the World Health Organisation said from neighbourig Congo on Thursday.
The figures given by WHO's Africa regional director Ebrahim Samba showed one more death and four new cases since the agency's last medical bulletin on Wednesday.
In that statement, WHO said four Ebola victims were in hospital in northeastern Gabon where the haemorrhagic virus killed 13 people in February.
Gabon confirmed on Tuesday that 14 people had caught the virus in the region since July 24. Ebola has a fatality rate of about 80 percent.
The first victim in the latest outbreak was a hunter suspected to have caught the virus in the forest. He died on August 23 in a hospital at Boue, east of the capital Libreville.
Samba said 40 people among 60 who came into contact with the victims were being observed by medical teams.
At least 13 people died in the area last February in an outbreak of Ebola, which is marked by fever, vomiting, diarrhoea and massive bleeding.
Health officials said then the virus broke out among families who ate or handled dead chimpanzees in the remote area.
Ebola is transmitted by direct contact with blood secretions or body fluids.
The virus struck in Kikwit, Zaire in May 1995, killing 245 people. A single victim in Ivory Coast last December survived.
